items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Torksey river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue.

Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road. Standing water remains in the surrounding area of Girton.

No further rainfall is forecast. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.

We expect river levels to remain high with Spring tides and snow melt until Wednesday, 15/01/2025.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.

Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and please do not drive through floodwater, as bow waves may affect adjacent properties.

To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.

This message will be updated by 17:00 today, 15/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Churn and its tributaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Churn, Hilcot Brook, Daglingworth Stream, Gumstool Brook

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are falling on the lower reaches of the river Churn. However, flooding of low lying land and roads is still possible today, 15/01/25, particularly in Cerney Wick.  It is forecast to remain dry for the next few days. We expect river levels to continue to fall slowly. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow, 16/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are stable or dropping along the River Windrush. Flooding of low lying land and roads remains possible today, 15/01/25, especially in the Bourton On The Water and Newbridge areas.  It is forecast to remain mostly dry for the next few days. We expect river levels to continue dropping slowly over the coming days. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow, 16/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.description: Lower Avon and tributaries

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
River levels are slowly falling but still remain high due to the previous rainfall.  We are continually monitoring the situation and the river levels.
All areas between Ringwood and Christchurch could be affected and include all tributaries. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Never drive through flood water, just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.
This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 15/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
Flood water is receding from the causeways at Earith, Sutton Gault and Welney.  Due to the uneven surface of the road, deep puddles may be encountered. The forecast is for no further rainfall for the next 5 days. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. 

Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Tern and Perry catchments
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Walcot River gauge following recent heavy rainfall and snowmelt. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is still possible.

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.  

No rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow, Thursday 16/01/25. We are closely monitoring the situation.  

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  

This message will be updated by 10am on 16/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Chertsey Bourne

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels continue to fall on the Chertsey Bourne, but may remain high for the coming days. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is still possible today, 15/01/25, especially in the Free Prae Road area of Chertsey. The forecast for the next few days is dry.  We are closely monitoring the situation. We expect river levels to continue to slowly fall over the coming days. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 16/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding in this area. The weather forecast for the next few days look dry and there is minimal chance of any further rainfall. 
There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: River Wye in Derbyshire
items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Ashford river gauge as a result of snowmelt. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Ashford and Bakewell areas.   
No further rainfall is forecast.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 11:00 tomorrow morning, 16/01/25, or as the situation changes

items.description: River Rye catchment
items.message: River levels have now started to fall in this area. We will continue to monitor the situation and re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.description: River Wiske and other tributaries of the River Swale

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Wiske, Brompton Beck, Cod Beck, North Beck, Willow Beck, Sun Beck, Winton Beck

items.message: This alert has been removed due to river levels falling back below levels of concern. We are closely monitoring the forecast and will reissue this alert if necessary.

items.description: West Somerset Streams

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message:
Flooding is still possible as the river near Beggearn Huish in West Somerset remains above the flood alert threshold of 0.35m following heavy rainfall two weekends ago. However, water levels look stable and continue to slowly fall. 
Tuesday's forecast predicts dry weather. While the Flood Alert may remain in place through till Wednesday, we are closely monitoring the weather forecast, river levels, and overall conditions. If the dry forecast holds, the alert could be lifted soon.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 15/01/2025, or if the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.60 mAOD at 15:45 on 15/01/25.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 115 cubic metres per second and is falling. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 20:00 on 15/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Swale

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Swale, Cod Beck, Bedale Beck

items.message: River levels have now started to fall in this area. We will continue to monitor the situation and re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.description: River Churnet and River Tean
Rivers Esk and Irthing
Lower River Ure

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ure, Swinney Beck, Bishop Monkton Beck, River Skell, River Laver, River Tutt, Stainley Beck

items.message: River levels have peaked, and are now falling on the lower River Ure. Flooding could still affect locations near the River Skell and River Ure, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around low-lying land including agricultural land and local roads in the areas around Masham, Boroughbridge, Aldborough and Bishop Monkton. We expect snow to continue to melt during Wednesday 15/01/25. River levels may remain high because of this. We are closely monitoring the situation and liaising with emergency services and local authorities. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 7:30pm on Wednesday 15/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ure at Boroughbridge Camping and Caravanning Site
items.message: This warning has been removed as river levels have fallen below the levels of concern.  Please continue to exercise caution around any remaining flood water on roads and footpaths.

items.description: Upper River Ouse

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message: Rising river levels this morning Wednesday, 15/01/2024 may lead to flooding as melting snow in the dales pushes river levels up. Flooding is forecast to affect locations around the River Ouse from Aldwark Bridge to Naburn Lock, including the City of York. Low-lying land and paths close to watercourses will be most affected. We expect snow melt to continue to during Wednesday 15/01/25 and river levels are forecast to peak in York on Wednesday morning. We are closely monitoring the situation and liaising with emergency services and local authorities.  The Foss Barrier is operating as required. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 8:00pm on 15/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
Middle River Aire catchment
items.message: River levels in the middle Aire catchment have fallen below levels of concern. No further significant rain is expected over the next few days. Please continue to take care near any standing water which may remain in fields or low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.

items.description: Lower Derwent in Derbyshire
items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Church Wilne river gauge as a result of snowmelt.   Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Church Wilne, Draycott, and Wilne Lane between Draycott and Sawley.   
No further rainfall is forecast.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 11:00 tomorrow morning, 16/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Nidd catchment
items.message: River levels are falling on the River Nidd. However, levels remain high in the Skip Bridge area, where water from the Nidd is joining high levels on the River Ouse. Levels in this area are expected to peak during Wednesday morning, 15/01/25. We are closely monitoring the situation and liaising with emergency services and local authorities. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 8:00pm on Wednesday15/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ouse at York - riverside properties
items.message: Rising river levels caused by melting snow in the upper catchments is expected to cause flooding this morning, Wednesday 15/01/25. Areas most at risk include properties on King's Staith in York and riverside areas through York from Lendal Bridge to Millennium Bridge. Flood gates in York have been closed and the Foss Barrier is operating as required. Levels in York are expected to peak on Wednesday morning, 15/01/25, and then begin to fall thereafter. Activate any property flood protection products you may have. This message will be updated by 2:00pm on 15/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Salisbury Plain area
items.message:
Groundwater levels remain high and are expected to respond to recent rainfall, levels are likely to respond from the 8th of January onwards. Levels are very reactive to further rainfall. 

Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 3 PM on 14/1/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Great Shefford area
items.message:
Groundwater levels are currently stable at our Northfield Farm borehole in the Great Shefford area. However, groundwater levels remain above normal for this time of year and are at a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the next week.

We expect levels to remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall, Low-lying land, roads and basements may be at risk of flooding.

Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message in a week, 21/01/2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message:
Groundwater levels are currently stable at our Longacre borehole in the Lambourn Valley. However, groundwater levels remain above normal for this time of year and communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the coming weeks if levels begin rising again.

We expect levels to remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall.  Low-lying land, roads and basements could be at risk of flooding.

Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message in a week, 21/01/2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Candovers and Old Alresford
items.message: Groundwater levels in the Candovers and Old Alresford are high and continue to slowly rise. In the last 7 days, the level at Preston Candover has risen by 19cm. In Preston Candover and Old Alresford, a small number of properties are expected to be experiencing cellar flooding. Septic tanks in Old Alresford will be struggling to operate effectively. Dry weather is forecast for the next week. Groundwater levels are expected to begin stabilising by this weekend. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Tuesday 21/01/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Flamstead
items.message: Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the Autumn and early Winter, and have risen to very high levels at our observation borehole at River Hill, close to Flamstead. Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high Autumn and early Winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads such as those in the Trowley Bottom area near Flamstead will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 15th January 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kimpton and Lilley Bottom
items.message: Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the Autumn and early Winter, and have risen to high levels at our observation borehole at Lilley Bottom. This rise is from levels which were already high from the previous Winter. Levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities in the Kimpton and Lilley Bottom area are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high Autumn and early Winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 15th January 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Ilsley, East Ilsley, Compton, Chilton and West Hagbourne
items.message:
Groundwater levels are currently rising very slowly at our Hodcott borehole near West Ilsley, East Ilsley and Compton following rainfall over recent weeks.

Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the next few weeks. We expect levels to continue rising slowly over the coming week and levels will remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall. Low-lying land and roads will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding.

Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, 21/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Nidd catchment
items.message: River levels have now started to fall in this area. We will continue to monitor the situation and re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.description: River Crimple catchment
items.message: River levels have now started to fall in this area. We will continue to monitor the situation and re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.description: Minor Watercourses from Heighington to Dunston
items.message: The risk of flooding from the minor watercourse associated with the Lower River Witham has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in villages surrounding Andover
items.message: Groundwater levels in the villages surrounding Andover are high and slowly rising. In the last week, the level at Clanville has risen by 60cm. In Appleshaw, a small number of properties are expected to begin experiencing cellar flooding from today (13/01/2025). In Hatherden, a small number of cellars could be affected from Wednesday (15/01/2025). Groundwater is affecting the sewerage network at Penton Mewsey and the main road into Penton Grafton is flooded. Groundwater will emerge in many of the ditches and roads in most villages. During this week, the weather is expected to remain mostly dry. Groundwater levels are expected to continue rising for another week in response to the rain recorded in early January. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please remove any valuables from cellars. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Monday 20/01/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Deane and Ashe in North Hampshire
items.message: In Deane and Ashe, groundwater levels are high and continue to rise slowly. In the last 7 days, the level has risen by 34cm. In the last 3 months, 265mm of rain has been recorded at Overton. This is more than the long-term average rainfall expected for this period. The River Test will be flowing in Deane and Ashe. Rising groundwater will also begin to affect the ability of septic tanks to operate properly. During this week, the weather will remain fairly dry, but groundwater will continue to rise for most of January, in response to the rainfall recorded at the beginning of the month. We continue to monitor the forecast. In Deane, we would like residents to prepare for cellar flooding impacts, which are possible by the end of January. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. We will update this Flood Alert by 17:00 on Monday 20/01/2025.
